effect: An Anchor is a sufficiently large Metal Source that is either sufficiently secured or heavy that a Metalbound can pull themselves towards it without moving it. Typically, a Metal Source of a Size greater than the Metalbound can be used as an Anchor.
An Attack is any Action that makes use of Chart and requires you to roll to determine the effect.

An Earthen Feature is a prominent above-ground Obstacle created primarily from earth or stone. Boulders and Earthen Bulwarks are obvious examples, but a stone wall or similar is also a valid Earthen Feature.
Any Attack that does not have a Damage column in its profile.

A Metal Source is any amount of metal sufficient for use by a Metalbound. Any Weapon that is crafted predominately of metal counts as a Metal Source as well as any similarly-sized metal objects in the environment, but using them in conjunction with Metalbound features will typically Damage them. A Metalbound can reduce their Armor value by 1 to create a Metal Source when wearing Armor made predominately of metal. If this reduces their Armor value to 0, the Metalbound is treated as Unarmored. Finally, a Metalbound is always assumed to be wearing sufficient metal for a single Source, so long as they have their gear on hand. After being used for an ability, track the location of all Metal Sources on the map.
A Phase is a part of a Round that exists to designate the speed at which different Techniques happen.
Punish Reactions take advantage of a brief opportunity in battle to make a sudden strike. Many Actions and abilities reference Punish Reactions.
Any Attack that has a Damage column in its Profile.
Sturdy Terrain has Resistance to all damage.
A Wielded item is held in one or both hands. Many Actions requires that a character be wielding a specific type of item to make use of them.

Move a target up to X squares directly towards you, where X is the numerical value immediately after Pull in an effect's description. If you are already adjacent, you may move the target up to X squares, as long as they end the movement directly adjacent to you.
Move a target up to X squares directly away, where X is the numerical value immediately after Push in an effect's description.
Move a target up to X squares in any direction.
